What does grief look like? My 9yo seems to have an attitude while at a restaurant for dinner & refuses to eat. After 15-20 min he starts crying. I asked if he was crying for Teresa & I figured out we were sitting at a table for 6 & now were 5. Now tell me covid isnt that bad.

One thing I do to stay human in this pandemic is to read any obituary I come across. If I see it—on Twitter, on email, in the newspaper, anywhere—I read every word of it. These were real people with whole lives & families & friends who loved them. They deserve to be remembered.

HealthcareHeroes Its the first day of the new year and many of us are enjoying time off. Here’s and important message from Sister Sarah Ramphisa from Park Care Centre in Joburg.
Prof Barry Schoub: Those with comorbidities will be in the second tier.VaccineStrategy

Prof Barry Schoub: Also the elderly particularly those who are in nursing homes, because they are at risk for complications. There are also key personnel other than healthcare workers and people in institutions. VaccineStrategy
Prof Barry Schoub: The top tier are the healthcare workers. In our role as the Advisory Committee, we have put healthcare workers at the top of our list for the vaccine. VaccineStrategy
Prof Barry Schoub: Ivermectin has been designed to treat worms. So far no clinical trial has shown that it is effective. VaccineStrategy

Safura Karim:There have been a lot of countries who started rolling out vaccines before Phase 3 approvals were granted.These were granted through emergency use. We haven’t taken this route, Our regulators are ensuring that any vaccine rolled out is comprehensively tested.

DDG Anban Pillay: Regulators will determine whether the vaccine works or not. They do that independently of government and pharmaceutical companies. The same goes for safety, regulators will confirm if the vaccine is safe or not. VaccineStrategy

DDG Anban Pillay: Suppliers do not have stock of the vaccines and most have agreements with countries first. When the vaccine does become available, it’ll be through government. VaccineStrategy @MorningLiveSABC
DDG Anban Pillay: COVAX has communicated to us that a date will be communicated in early January. Once this date is given, we will communicate it VaccineStrategy @MorningLiveSABC
Prof Barry Schoub: The Pfizer vaccine after the first shot is only about 50% effective. That is why a second shot is given. VaccineStrategy @MorningLiveSABC

DDG Anban Pillay: We have not delayed the procurement at all. We took a decision that we would go with the COVAX Facility rather than taking risks and going with one vaccine supplier. This is a safer mechanism and we are about 1 of 198 countries procuring. VaccineStrategy

Collaboration between the private and public health sectors will be key to the successful implementation of this life-saving intervention.
This strategy will include a review of available resources, services delivery platforms, and the required investment to ensure a successful administration to the selected priority groups.

To support SA’s efforts to secure early access to, and delivery of, safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines and treatments as soon as they become available, the MAC on COVID-19 Vaccines has been developing a strategy for the implementation of a COVID-19 vaccination rollout.

Nevertheless SAHPRA has committed to ensuring the expeditious evaluation of these vaccines once the dossiers have been received, through various mechanisms that will shorten the timeframe it usually takes to approve a product.

Before a vaccine can be rolled out the South African Health Products Regulatory Authority (SAHPRA) must assess the safety, efficacy and quality of the vaccine. None of the vaccine manufacturers have submitted their application dossiers to SAHPRA as yet.

We will be engaging these vaccine manufacturers to and we also wish to reassure SAns that, while the COVAX Facility is our favoured vehicle for accessing vaccines, we will always explore all options to ensure that the process of rolling out vaccines is safe and cost effective.

SA’S ACCESS TO COVID-19 VACCINES As announced by his excellency President MC Ramaphosa, SA remains a member state of the COVAX facility and still holds its strategic position as co-chair of the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator (ACT-A), of which COVAX is a major component

Some countries such as China and Russia have developed their own vaccines, while other countries have entered into bilateral agreements with individual companies. There are four candidate vaccines that have been studied in the South African population.
These vaccines are produced by Astra Zeneca, Novavax, Johnson&Johnson and Pfizer/ BioNTech. The other vaccines producers are also seeking to conduct trials in South Africa.

Acc to @WHO , COVID19 is caused by the novel coronavirus, which spreads between people, mainly when an infected person is in close contact with another person. The virus can spread from an infected person’s mouth or nose in small liquid particles when they... (1/3) https://twitter.com/meenmani/status/1383274952372023301…

...cough, sneeze, speak, sing or breathe heavily. These liquid particles are of different sizes, ranging from larger ‘respiratory droplets’ to smaller ‘aerosols’. As per @CDCgov , these minuscule airborne particles can travel farther than 6 feet, particularly when people... (2/3)

...are talking, singing, or even breathing heavily in indoor environments with poor ventilation. So it is possible for a person to get infected with COVID19 if he/she is standing close to a person who is smoking tobacco COVID_19 COVID__19 COVID COVIDー19 coronavirus (3/3)

Another Paxlovid relapse case, adding to our concerns about the 5-day blister pack length of treatment with a variant (BA.2/BA2.12.1) not assessed in the clinical trials (w/ very rare rebound). Given the importance of Paxlovid as a backstop Rx, this needs to be urgently addressed

There are currently no cases of MarburgVirusDisease in Nigeria. However, measures have been taken to strengthen preparedness for MVD in Nigeria. This week, we conducted a National Multisectoral Coordination Mechanisms Operational Tool workshop with participants from relevant MDAs & partners The MCM-OT will help strengthen the existing national One Health mechanism and establish a template for sub-national implementation.

Colleagues @NCDCgov and partners are working round the clock battling Lassa Fever in all but 11 States. Health workers on the frontlines continue to step up on containment efforts. During this Healthworkersweek I really would like to celebrate all who are leading this charge!

It's WorldHealthDay and WHO75 The theme 'HealthForAll' calls on the world including Nigeria to take required actions which can help tackle health challenges today and tomorrow. Everyone everywhere deserves equitable access to basic health services. UniversalHealthCoverage

Today, we held a refresher training on the 7-1-7 framework, for our disease technical working groups & stakeholders, supported by @ResolveTSL . This framework is a real-time, start-to-end assessment of the turnaround time for the detection & control of infectious disease threats.

This year, 784 confirmed cases of LassaFever and 142 deaths have been reported across 23 States in Nigeria. Read more on the epidemiological situation of LassaFever in Nigeria and our response activities via https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria…

LassaFever spreads majorly to humans through direct contact, eating food, or drinking water contaminated with urine, faeces, saliva, or blood of infected rats. Store your foodstuff in rodent-proof containers Maintain a clean environment always Practice hand hygiene

CerebrospinalMeningitis (CSM) is an easily transmissible disease with confirmed cases reported all year round in Nigeria. Download our latest CSM situation report for a summary of the disease situation and our response activities https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=6&name=An%20Update%20of%20Meningitis%20Outbreak%20in%20Nigeria… TakeResponsibility

As health emergencies happen more often, vulnerabilities in communities and underinvestment in public health leave dangerous gaps in preparedness and response. Today we hosted national public health agencies at @WHO to look at how we can close the gaps.

This week, DG @IfedayoTiffy is attending @WHO 's consultation with National Public Health Agencies in Geneva, Switzerland He provided updates on Nigeria's implementation of preparedness & response capacities for public health emergencies with a focus on collaborative surveillance

Reducing the burden of AntimicrobialResistance does not happen in silos. So in our AMR Health and Hygiene Clubs, we love seeing our DRASAAmbassadors discuss in groups how they can work together to promote health and prevent AMR in their communities.

Immunization plays a critical role; • It helps to secure the future of our children and community. • It prevents early childhood death. • Families become more productive. • It prevents childhood diseases. • Immunization saves lives. Can you add to the list?

@NCDCgov works closely with PHS in the execution of its mandate. Today, we handed over four fully equipped Toyota ambulances to PHS for use at our airports and other POEs to manage natural or man-made events requiring action to save lives and protects property and public health!

The NCDC collaborates with principal actors on cross border disease surveillance. The Port Health Services (PHS) of @Fmohnigeria responsible for the reduction of morbidity, mortality and disability due to communicable and non-communicable diseases at Points of Entry/Exit (POEs).

Cholera is a waterborne disease, with a higher risk of transmission when there is poor sanitation and disruption of clean water supply. Practice and ensure the use of safe water in your homes and communities. TakeResponsibility

Strengthening Nigeria’s national health security is a joint responsibility Today, the NCDC donated fully equipped emergency response ambulances to the Port Health Services, @Fmohnigeria . We remain committed to protecting the health of Nigerians. StrongerTogether

Are you an incoming traveller to Nigeria Fill out the Nigeria Health Declaration Form via https://healthapp.ncdc.gov.ng Carefully verify that all filled details are correct Submit the form and download a copy It is FREE of charge.

Cholera is easily transmitted in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene. TakeResponsibility to practice and ensure physical and environmental hygiene in your homes and community. To learn more about cholera, visit: https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/factsheet/50…

Dear Healthcare Worker, Remember that many infections present with similar signs and symptoms. Always maintain a high index of suspicion. Test, and then treat.

Parents & caregivers should ensure that their children/wards receive the anti-diphtheria vaccine as recommended in the @NphcdaNG childhood immunisation schedule. Visit a primary health care centre close to you to get the vaccine. TakeResponsibility

Cases of cholera are recorded mostly during the rainy season To prevent the spread of cholera, Nigerians are urged to: Only consume water from safe sources Stop open defaecation Dispose of refuse and waste properly Ensure proper drainage of sewage

Cholera spreads through food or water contaminated by the faeces of an infected person. Make your water and food safe: Drink only water from safe sources Do not defaecate around water sources Eat thoroughly cooked foods Wash fruits & vegetables properly with clean water

TakeResponsibility for you, your family, friends, and community. If you or anyone is at risk for diphtheria, ensure that they get vaccinated. Why? Because VaccinesWork and there is a widely available & very safe vaccine that protects against diphtheria. Get vaccinated today!

Individuals at higher risk of diphtheria infection are advised to get vaccinated against diphtheria. Visit a primary health care centre close to you to get the vaccine. TakeResponsibility to stay safe and healthy

Our diphtheria NCDCRRT across states continues to support State teams in the ongoing outbreak response. Activities carried out include contact tracing, lab support, advocacy to traditional leaders, sensitisation of healthcare workers, risk communication & health promotion etc.

Today, DG @IfedayoTiffy received the Chair, @AFENETAfrica Board of Directors, Prof Ernest Kenu and other delegates on a visit to NCDC. @AfenetNigeria through NFELTP graduates and residents have been very pivotal to strong field epidemiology and outbreak response in Nigeria.

We also have Rapid Response teams Teams in Kano, Lagos, Osun & Yobe helping with the Diphtheria response. And in Jigawa & Yobe for meningitis. Although it feels like we are under siege given the concurrent disease outbreaks, the @NCDCgov will keeppushing onwardsandupwards.

Diphtheria is a serious infectious disease caused by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae bacterium. It primarily affects the respiratory system, symptoms include sore throat, fever, swollen glands and weakness. PreventEpidemicsNaija

Symptoms of diphtheria include fever, runny nose, sore throat, cough, red eyes, swollen neck & in severe cases, a thick grey/white patch at the back of the throat with difficulty breathing Visit a health facility close to you for diagnosis & treatment https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/435/diphtheria-public-health-advisory-amidst-outbreak-in-nigeria…

A suspected case of LassaFever is any individual with a fever for 3-21 days with symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhoea, sore throat, muscle pain, generalized body weakness, abnormal bleeding, and abdominal pain. 15/n. If you have received one booster dose already, please go get your second booster dose. If you belong in any of the high-risk categories (old age, etc), kindly ensure you adhere to recommended public health safety measures – mask use, hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces.

14/n. We advise Nigerians to make use of every opportunity the Federal Government has provided via the @NphcdaNG to get vaccinated i.e., receive your primary vaccination which can be two or a single vaccine dose. If you have received two vaccine doses already, go get your booster

13/n. ...severe disease, admissions and deaths among the under or unvaccinated and those with established risk factors – old age, cardiovascular and endocrine co-morbidity, immune suppressive states (disease and/or treatments), etc.

12/n. The Nigerian COVID-19 response continues to be executed via 4 pillars – continued surveillance, genomics surveillance, capacity for surge testing and vaccination. Regardless of SARS-CoV-2 variants in different parts of the world, there continues to be an excess of cases...

11/n. BQ.1.1 took over in Sep2022 and persisted since then. None of these were associated with any increases in case numbers, admissions or deaths. We have not detected BF.7 or XBB.1.5 in country yet (sequencing updates for Dec2022 are in progress).

10/n. In Nigeria, @NCDCgov continues with genomic surveillance. The omicron variant was first detected in Dec2021 and has since become the dominant strain. BQ.1/BQ.1.1 and related sub lineages were first seen in Nigeria from July 2022 and BQ.1 became the dominant from Aug2022...

9/n. BF.7 is also thought to be highly transmissible and sufficiently immune evading. In addition, the ‘poor immune status' of the Chinese population now exposed to high levels of transmission of a rapidly mutating virus may favour the rapid emergence of new variants of concern.

8/n ...is a source of worry as it may spread faster than older omicron sub lineages e.g., XBB or BQ and cause increases in hospitalisation when it becomes dominant. BF.7 (BA.5.2.1.7) is considered responsible for the surge in China but does not appear to be increasing elsewhere.

7/n...with BQ.1 increasing from Nov to 23/12/22 and XBB detected at very low levels from Oct2022. On 30/12/22, @CDC projections were that XBB.1.5 will make up 40.5% of COVID-19 cases. In England, XBB.1.5 went up quickly from Nov22 to about 1.9% of cases as at 24/12/22. XBB.1.5...

6/n As at 03/12/22, BQ.1.1, BQ.1, BA.5 and BF.7 were responsible for 85.1% of cases in the US and XBB.1.5 made up 1.3%. For England, BA.5 (17.1%), BA.2.75 (16.6%) and BQ.1 (59.6%) were dominant (up to 27/12/22). In South Africa BA.5 and sub lineages dominated in Sept-Nov 2022...

5/n...admissions in Dec2022 vs Nov22 (as at 21/12/22). Prior to the current uptick in cases seen in China, the US, the UK and elsewhere, genomic surveillance continued to show the Omicron SARS-CoV-2 variant and its lineage continued to predominate in infections worldwide.

4/n @UKHSA data show 28.8%, 36.3% and 1.6% increases in cases, admissions and deaths (as at 22/12/22 compared to previous period). @CDCgov reports 57.0%, 23.2% and 66.0% increases in cases, admissions and deaths as at 21/12/22 compared to 20/11/22. @HealthZA data shows fewer...

3/n...backdrop of a population that neither has high levels of natural immunity nor high levels of coverage with vaccines with the greatest impact against severe disease, hospitalisation, and death. Cases, admissions & deaths in the England and the US have increased significantly

2/n Our COVID-19 EOC is tracking COVID-19 trends in China, US, UK, South Africa, India and other destinations with high volume traffic to and from Nigeria. The COVID-19 resurgence in China is not surprising giving their recent transition from a zero COVID-19 strategy against a...

1/n The @NCDCgov follows global COVID-19 epidemiology including genomics data as part of the ongoing pandemic response. The NCDC COVID-19 EOC continues to function at level 2 alertness - includes weekly risk assessments to inform the need for action e.g., travel restrictions.

REDNESS OF THE EYE is an early indication of Measles when observed with symptoms like high-grade fever, running nose, dry cough & tiny spots in the mouth. Please report immediately to a health facility when these symptoms are observed. Visit https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/info/M for more.

Nigerians are advised to continue to TakeResponsibility. Self-isolate if you test positive for COVID19 until you recover. Adhere to guidelines for home-based care of mild COVID19 cases: https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/COVID19PatientsBookforHomebasedCare.pdf… Public Health Advisory: https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/429/public-health-advisory-following-the-presidential-approval-for-the-relaxation-of-covid-19-safety-measures-%26-travel-advisory…
Measles is highly contagious. Isolate all suspected cases of the disease and take them to the nearest health care facility immediately. Read more via https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/info/M

AntimicrobialStewardship (AMS) instituted at the global, national & subnational levels is recognised as a major strategy to tackle AMR Our peer-reviewed article appraises the factors influencing the implementation of AMS in Nigerian health facilities https://sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213716522001977?via%3Dihub…

Measles is an acute, highly infectious disease with initial symptoms of high fever, cough, runny nose, red eyes & tiny white spots in the mouth. Please immediately report to a health facility if you experience these symptoms. Read more: https://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/info/M

This best practice initiative, starts 3rd Jan 2023, & is welcomed at the NCDC and comes as we develop our next 5-year strategic plan to ensure ownership and sustainability. Grateful for the tremendous support and work by the @USCDCNIGERIA , @Georgetown and @WHONigeria .

The PHEMCoE is one of the components of the @CDCgov @CDCGlobal @USCDCNIGERIA Advancing Capacity for Epidemic Preparedness and Response in Nigeria (ACEPRIN) grant, for institutional strengthening & outbreak response that @NCDCgov has been implementing since October 2020.

The Public Health Emergency Management Center of Excellence PHEMCoE is a global initiative that integrates controlled processes, quality improvement & standards, adopted by National Public Health Institutes to prevent, detect, respond & recover from public health emergencies.

TodayInNCDC, our DG @IfedayoTiffy & top management, @Georgetown , @CDCgov & @WHO launched the PHEMCoE Nigeria project This project will combine the @GHSAgenda , IHR Joint External Evaluation, NPHI Staged Development Tool & various emergency preparedness & response capabilities

Ebola Travel Advisory Avoid all but essential travel to UGANDA Avoid contact with obviously sick persons/EVD suspected cases Call 6232 (free of charge) if you have recently returned from Uganda within the past 21 days & feel symptoms of EVD https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/423/public-health-advisory-following-declaration-of-ebola-virus-disease-outbreak-in-uganda…

Our responsibility now is to protect the drugs that we have so that we can slow down the rate of resistance. We should use the few working antimicrobial drugs that we have today, responsibly. – @ProfOduyebo WAAW2022

Humans too develop AntimicrobialResistance from food-producing animals, where a resistant microbes share genetic information from animal products (milk, eggs, meat) handling the animals, transporting, exporting across countries, or ingesting them as food. – @ZoKadri WAAW2022

Antimicrobial use in humans is different from food-producing animals, even though we share the same pathogens. The difference is in quantity/dosage, reason for use, growth promotion. This is why the food business sector needs to be involved in AMR. – Dr. @ZoKadri WAAW2022

Years ago, before Antimicrobials were discovered, simple cases of boil, diarrhoea or wound from surgery could lead to death. If AntimicrobialResitance is uncurbed, a time will come when infections will no longer be treatable with the drugs we have now. – Dr. @ZoKadri WAAW2022
"Whether you're a doctor who gives antimicrobials or a patient who receives it, we must all learn to handle antimicrobials with care." – Prof. @ProfOduyebo WAAW2022

COVID19 home-based care is recommended for patients who do not show symptoms of the disease or have only mild symptoms such as headache, fever or fatigue. Patients & caregivers are advised to strictly follow the home-based care guide https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/COVID19PatientsBookforHomebasedCare.pdf…

AntimicrobialResistance is when medicines like antimalarials, tetracycline, septrin, Amoxycillin no longer treat diseases they cure previously. Using antimicrobials "anyhow " is making the treatment of common infections more difficult. WorldAntimicrobialAwarenessWeek2022

Monkeypox is preventable. Avoid contact with sick/dead animals Cook all animal meats & products properly before eating Wash hands after handling animals & caring for/visiting sick people Avoid close/skin-to-skin contact with infected persons or persons showing symptoms

National public health institutes NPHIs are key to strengthening health security through coordination of preparedness for preventing disease outbreaks, and the response when they occur. Yesterday, I was glad to discuss Nigeria’s experience with @NCDCgov with the @DOHgovph team

Home-based care refers to when a laboratory-confirmed COVID19 patient is provided with required medical care at home. Care is provided by an assigned caregiver who may be a family member, a friend, or an identified person. Read https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/COVID19PatientsBookforHomebasedCare.pdf…

Healthcare workers are most at risk of person-to-person transmission of LassaFever. Always maintain a high index of suspicion for LassaFever and practice standard precautions always while attending to patients. Healthcare workers advisory: https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/351/lassa-fever-healthcare-workers-advisory…

Today, the NCDCTeam led by DG @IfedayoTiffy held a bilateral knowledge-sharing session with @DOHgovph . The session focused on our best practices & model of resource mobilisation to effectively mount a public health response against infectious disease threats. StrongerTogether

AntimicrobialResistance is a global concern affecting everyone, everywhere, including users & non-users of antimicrobials. Antimicrobials include antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals & antiparasitics used to prevent/treat infections in humans, animals & plants. WAAW2022

In a bid to tackle the threat of the third wave, Crypto Relief supported the @DFYIndia initiative to ensure preparedness of health infrastructure in the rural areas.

During this Omicron crisis in January 2022, with the support of @CryptoRelief_ , @DFYIndia supported and helped run 11 COVID hospitals with more than 1250 beds, including 130 ICU and HDU beds, as well as pediatric COVID care, COVID home isolation, and COVID testing & vaccination

@CryptoRelief supported the Udyogini foundation to make available food, nutrition and medical aids to the vulnerable families in Uttarakhand and Madhya Pradesh. The project focused on creating awareness about vaccines through mobile vans and provided medical aids to families.

Uttarakhand and Madhya Pradesh were identified as the most vulnerable places where the families needed immediate COVID relief and support. Mawai and Joshimath were the two remotest blocks that were selected in the states to implement this project. cryptorelief socialimpact
CryptoRelief supported Parivaar organisation’s initiative to provide freshly cooked meals twice a day to the needy in 30 villages of Madhya Pradesh. socialimpact covid pandemic crypto cryptorelief

Second wave of Covid left many poor and vulnerable families without any source of support. They not only lost their daily income and assets, but also their sources of food. This placed them at greater risk of hunger and low immunity due to undernourishment. COVID19 pandemic

To help these communities, @CryptoRelief_ supported the initiative by @CIF02 (Children of India Foundation) to provide ration kits to many vulnerable families across different states of the country during the pandemic! CryptoNews Socialimpact

This initiative helped families take care of their immunity and strength to fight COVID-19 through the distribution of healthy diet kits that fit local consumption patterns. It helped to provide food security, fight malnutrition and reduce the impact of COVID-19 on children.

CryptoRelief supported the @goonj Relief and rehabilitation efforts towards Covid-19 by providing food and medical facilities to the affected communities such as the differently abled, HIV+, sex workers, devadasis and many more covid pandemic socialimpact covid_19

@CryptoRelief_ CryptoRelief supported the self reliant initiative- Swastha Pahad by Joint Action @srijanofficial and Society for Himalayan Ecology and Geography (SHEG) in collaboration with multiple NGOs, SHGs, and individuals on the ground to save villages in Uttarakhand.

'Swastha Pahad' initiative focused on COVID relief work, covering 750+ villages in remote areas across the hill districts of Uttarakhand, with a population of more than a million people, mostly women and children. Socialimpact covid cryptocurrency

They protected us. CovidMemorialDay

THADDEAUS GOODLOW died of COVID on April 7, 2020. He was a US army veteran, a retired firefighter, and City inspector. "My mother, [DeLois] was able to say goodbye because she was in the same hospital room. They were married for 63 years."

DAVID ATKINSON, 60, of Tennessee, died of COVID on April 7, 2021. "When my grandmother died a terrible death that shattered our family he was there to console our family. I don't believe in God anymore, but David was the kind of person I hope to be remembered as."

@AlexJGoldstein , founder of @FacesOfCOVID , recently launched a companion project to create space to remember those lost to many other deadly illnesses. Approaching the 3rd anniversary of her passing, I shared my cousin's story. Love you forever, Sar. You deserved so much better.

CYNTHIA PEAK, 61, of Nashville, Tennessee, was shot to death in the school where she taught on March 27, 2023. "Her favorite roles in life were being a mom to her three children, a wife to her husband, and an educator to students. We will never stop missing her..."

ALICE JETT, 83 of Arkansas, died of COVID on March 30, 2020. She "was one of the most caring people I have ever known.. She was very devoted to God & attended Bible studies & volunteered at the Church for as long as she could...She will be so terribly missed."

KATHERINE KOONCE, 62, of Nashville, Tennessee, was shot to death in the school where she worked as Head of School on March 27, 2023. Her family described her as "devoted to her family, her friends and especially the children she cared for."
DAMIEN JACKSON, 42, of Columbia, South Carolina, died of COVID on March 29, 2021. He was a beloved teacher and coach at Dreher High School. “Damien didn’t just love, he was made of love.”
Hallie Scruggs, age 9, of Nashville, Tennessee, was shot to death in her school on March 27, 2023. She was in the third grade.

MEDARDO RABONZA, 76, of California, died of COVID on March 29, 2021. "His passion and delight was working on cars. He enjoyed watching movies especially westerns, wartime, and science fiction films. He loved his coffee and even learned ballroom dancing."

MIKE HILL, 61, of Nashville, Tennessee, was shot to death in the school where he worked as a custodian on March 27, 2023. “We pray for the Covenant School and are so grateful that Michael was beloved by the faculty and students who filled him with joy for 14 years..."

EVELYN DIECKHAUS, age 9, of Nashville, Tennessee, was shot to death in her school on March 27, 2023. “Our hearts are completely broken. We cannot believe this has happened...Evelyn was a shining light in this world.”

LENORE KLEBANOFF of Long Beach, New York, died of COVID on March 29, 2020. "Mom was an avid reader and chocolate lover! Her family was her world and she is missed by all of children and grandchildren."
JOHN BILJAN, 57, of Melbourne, Florida, died of COVID on March 20, 2020. "John was an amazing father, husband and person. He is missed everyday."
This week will mark his 40th birthday. It hurts, was looking forward to joking with him over it. Still missing you.

MARY STEVENS, 58, of Derry, New Hampshire, died of breast cancer on Feb. 22, 2023. "Mary was a devoted wife, mother, sister, and friend, who cherished spending time with her family, creating countless memories that will be treasured forever." https://legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/mary-ferris-stevens-obituary?id=48272846…

MICHAEL GORDY, 70, of Tucson, Arizona, died of COVID on March 18, 2021. He was a beloved educator and community activist "who was often running late because of an important cause that needed his immediate attention."
STEVE SHULMAN, 67, of Seattle, Washington, died of COVID on March 18, 2020. He was a legendary community leader and grocer at Leschi's Market on Lake Washington.

AUSTIN POHL, 35, of Westphalia, Michigan, died of COVID on March 18, 2021. "Austin...embodied the idea that although life's circumstances can at time bring us to our knees, what matters is that we keep looking up & moving forward."
ALVIN SIMMONS, 54, of Rochester, New York, died of COVID on March 17, 2020. He was a veteran of the US Army and worked in the environmental services department of Rochester General Hospital.

DOLORES NABORS VALASTRO, 88, of Denton, Texas, died of COVID on March 17, 2021. "She was greatly loved by so many. A deeply kind and spiritual soul who believed that we are all connected. The world feels empty without her. I will miss you the rest of my life, mom."

DUMISANI LONGWE, 29, of Seattle, Washington, died of an accidental fentanyl overdose on Jan. 7, 2023. "...we are devastated, in pain, shocked and numb but we would like to share our story so that not another family should ever go through what we have." https://legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/dumisani-longwe-obituary?id=38646008…

DORIS BUVELOT-HARKINS, 36, of California, died of synovial sarcoma cancer on Feb. 25, 2023. "She immediately lit up any room she entered and touched so many lives, having had a positive impact on friends and strangers alike." https://legacy.com/us/obituaries/sfgate/name/doris-buvelot-harkins-obituary?n=doris-buvelot-harkins&pid=204093437…
BRITTANY BODZAK, 35, of Forked River, New Jersey, died of COVID on March 17, 2021. "She left behind a month old daughter, an 18 month old son and a 6 year old son. She is dearly loved and missed."
Heartbreaking...

On this COVID Remembrance/Memorial Day, support @MarkedByCovid Massachusetts in establishing the day. Send a letter of support to your legislators. We can't prevent what we are not willing to acknowledge. Help us remember. CovidRemembranceDay mapoli
This thread!

On this CovidMemorialDay, I'm revisiting this series of videos I created with the help of a few incredibly talented folks at the pandemic's peak. They offer a small window into the enormity of what we've lost and continue to lose.
We will never forget them.
They tried to save as many as they could. CovidMemorialDay
They taught us. CovidMemorialDay

How do you mourn the losses of over a million people? It starts with CovidMemorialDay on Monday, March 6 at 8:00pm ET. Join @MarkedByCovid for a vigil w/ our legislative champs: Senator @ewarren and Representative @gregstantonaz For more information >> http://covidmemorialday.org/vigil

BOBBY CLEMENTS, 51, of Simms, Texas, died of COVID on March 5, 2022. "Family was the most important thing to Bobby. He enjoyed spending quality time with family & friends fishing, hunting, camping, or just simply sitting on the back porch or in the shop."
"Five residents of a South Yarmouth nursing home died in recent days following an outbreak of COVID-19, which also caused more than 90 additional cases among residents and staff."

LORI JEAN DOHERTY, 65, of Green Bay, Wisconsin, died of COVID on March 5, 2022. "If she was not with her grandchildren you would find her showing off photos...to anyone who would look. She couldn't go more than a day without seeing or facetiming with her little grandbabies!"

Starting up the March 2023of incidents of antisemitic violence, intimidation, graffiti, and threats across the United States. This is the 5th month in a row trying to compile these in one place. The most recent (February) thread is particularly bleak (link below).

DONALD APPLEGATE, 66, of Phoenix, Arizona, died of COVID on March 4, 2021. "While Don passed too soon, his life will always be remembered by family, friends for his honesty, integrity, intelligence, positivity and sense of humor."

BARRY DOSS, 46, of Beaumont, Texas, died of COVID on Feb. 6, 2022. "He was a Recovery Coach for people recovering from addiction...He loved helping people and his mission in life was helping others through their recovery journey."
JUDITH WOODRUFF, 62, of Hinton, West Virginia, died of COVID on Jan. 31, 2023. "She loved spending time with her family, sewing and attending church as long as her health permitted."

CAROL MACKEY, 85, of White Rock, New Mexico, died of COVID on Feb. 5, 2021. She "loved cats, picnics, bright colors, and seeing where the road, the trail, or the unopened door might lead. She turned friends into family and taught all of us to love without limits."

EMILY THOMPSON, 37, of Lexington, Kentucky, died of COVID on Feb. 5, 2022. "She loved crocheting, drawing, playing cards and any pets the family ever had. Left to cherish her memory is her son, the light of her life, Matthew..."

Friends, please add @FacesOfCOVID The creator has worked diligently in creating a site to honor the beautiful souls we lost to COVID. 1.8 million Americans are no longer with us. They MATTERED! Their lives MATTERED!

JESSICA HART, 36, of South Ogden, Utah, died of COVID on Feb. 5, 2022. "...she loved helping others and she devoted much of her time and energy into helping the less fortunate by donating to women's shelters and the food bank. She was our sunflower and will forever be missed."

JOSE ARTURO RAMIREZ MEDINA, 42, of Rockwall, Texas, died of COVID on Feb. 4., 2021. "He will be best remembered for his noble heart. He worked in concrete for 26+ years. He loved being productive by working on his truck & had a green thumb..."

ELIZABETH "BETTY" BENDES of Bay City, Michigan, died of COVID on Feb. 3, 2021. "My grandmother was such a huge supporter of me and everyone else lucky enough to be in her life. She loved card games (especially Phase 10) and Taco Bell and fudgesicles and her family."

KELLY HENDERSON BRADLEY, 43, of Greenville, Pennsylvania, died of COVID on Feb. 2, 2021. "A vibrant young LPN who touched a whole community of people, loving & nurturing...she dove head first into taking care of all our sick elderly, our healthcare system failed her terribly."

The good news is, it's not that hard to model empathy and compassion as a balance to the fear and anger and outrage (which I am not saying is unjustified). But we need folks to check in and see their stake in taking care of each other, not check out because it's all so bleak.

A rabbi here in Boston that was very close with my father when I was growing up, told me a few weeks before the start of the pandemic that one of America's biggest epidemics is loneliness, and I think about it everyday. It's so palpable. That will take a lot of work to repair.

There is a reason why many viral stories in our feeds are mundane moments from day to day life where someone helps an elderly neighbor cross a street or a Good Samaritan helps someone in crisis. With so much darkness, people want to feel that they're part of a community.

A reflection from 3 yrs of @FacesOfCOVID is that because much of the news people consume everyday is dripping with fear, anger, & outrage, many are desperate for reasons to give a shit about each other, & when you remind them why they should without judgement, many will respond.

PHILLIP LEE, 79, of Hatboro, Pennsylvania, died of COVID on Feb. 1, 2021. "An Air Force Vet, Phil worked in Computer Software and Systems Engineering retiring from Lockheed Martin...Dad was an amazing father and Papa to 2 young grandsons - always supportive and loving."

CATHERINE VILLANI, 49, of Shrewsbury, New Jersey, died of COVID on Jan. 18, 2021. A devoted pre-K reacher, "she found such joy in touching little lives and gave every piece of her heart while working with them for over 25 years."

PATTY CONTRERAS, 79, of Illinois, died of COVID on Jan. 25, 2021. "Auntie Pat was always the life of the party & the best hugger on the planet! Her warmth & positive glow were always delightful to be around & she had the ability to make everyone around her feel truly loved."

MARY ROXANNE TEAL, 70, of Tulare, California, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2021. A retired school bus driver and pizza shop owner, "she loved gardening and spending time with her grandchildren. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched..."

KAYLYNN KINGERY, 66, of Detroit, Michigan, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2022. "If you knew Kaylynn, you knew what it meant to be loved. She was the matriarch of our family and her memory will keep us warm until we meet again."
DONNA KIRKWOOD, 54, of Bloomington, Illinois, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2022. "Donna worked at CVS downtown Bloomington for 21-years.She was deeply loved and will be missed dearly."
This is my friend. I miss you, Carrie.

SONNY FOX, 95, of Encino, California, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2021. "...he was a WWII vet and POW captured at the Battle of the Bulge. He wouldn’t speak of his experience for many years...He was especially proud that he was liberated on Passover, his own personal Exodus."

MIKE LONGMAN, 75, of Sandy, Utah, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2021. "My dad was compassionate and loving beyond words. He gave everything he had to his family. He loved Jack Nicklaus, BYU football, and his faith. He was patient and kind in ways I'll never forget."

CARLA TOPEL, 88 of Bakersfield, California, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2021. "Carla was an incredibly loving grandmother and mother to all who knew her. We wish she was still here. She will be deeply missed."

CARRIE HENRY, 54, of Dayton, Ohio, died of COVID on Jan. 24, 2022. "She loved her family, friends & her students. Carrie loved to travel with her friends, go to concerts & she loved to dance! She touched a lot of lives & is deeply missed by all who were fortunate to know her."

TYLER JONES, 30, of Panama City, Florida, died of COVID on Jan. 19, 2021. "Tyler and Nicole enjoyed almost five years of a beautiful marriage, in which Tyler would greet Nicole every morning with a cup of espresso and a smile to brighten her day."

KRISTIN WHALEN, 30, of Sunderland, Massachusetts, died of COVID on Jan. 19, 2022. "She was thoughtful, caring and humble with a bright smile and blueberry eyes. She enjoyed hikes with her dog, gardening, cooking, baking, reading and feeding birds."

JOSE VILA, 74, of Miami, Florida, died of COVID on Jan. 19, 2021. "Jose was a deep thinker, a lover of nature, an advocate for a more just world. He loved history and poetry, but it was literature that 'saved him' from a difficult childhood. His children miss him profoundly."

CARL BENTON, 79, of McKinney, Texas, died of COVID on Jan. 19, 2021. My Dad was a kind and compassionate soul. He loved the Lord with all his heart. Hard worker, honest & caring. We miss him terribly. He was an active, healthy & fit 80 year old. He was not finished with life."
On this day in 2020, a total of 282 laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID had been reported in four countries: China (278 cases), Thailand (2 cases), Japan (1 case) and the Republic of Korea (1 case).

GRANT EGLEY, of Lake Waccamaw, North Carolina, died of COVID on Jan. 7, 2023. "Grant estimated that he had run more than 68,000 miles - more than two and a half times around the Earth - including 132 marathons and ultramarathons (any race longer than 26.2 miles)."

CATHERINE COPETILLO, 70, of Highland, California, died of COVID on Jan. 18, 2021. "Cat was a very strong woman. She raised her 4 children to love God. She loved you & you always knew where she stood. We will never forget her. See you in Paradise our precious & beautiful Mama."

SHARON HICKS, 77, of Tehachapi, California, died of COVID on Jan. 18, 2021. "My Mom was sweet, silly, and so fun. She loved us all so and always knew what to say to mend a skinned knee or a broken heart...I would call her every morning and say "Good morning Mamacita!"

RICHARD WALTON, 86, of Asheville, North Carolina, died of breakthrough COVID on Jan. 18, 2022. "He always fought for the underdog, whether he was treating patients in the 1980s with AIDS, who no other doctors would care for, or advocating for health insurance for all."

SOMPHONE DAOHEUANG, 36, of Minneapolis, Minnesota, died of COVID on Nov. 3, 2021. "I never got the chance to say my goodbye but I can say the last words I got to say to him was 'I love you bro' and his last words he said to me was 'I love you too sis'..."

PHYLLIS SKALIOTIS, 87, of West Warwick, Rhode Island, died of COVID on Jan. 8, 2023. "Phyllis never met a stranger, she could talk to anyone and loved meeting people who shared her love of life and music."

ROBERT GAUTIER, 74, of North Bergen, New Jersey, died of COVID on Jan. 14, 2021. "My dad was one of a kind, funny, always making up jokes, hardworking, and lived for each day...He was a friend to everyone, would give you the shirt off his back! We miss him so much everyday!"

JUDY THENHAUS, 81 of Cedar Rapids, Iowa died of COVID on Jan. 14, 2021. "My mom loved her husband, three daughters, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Several months ago she talked my dad into getting a puppy which she named Charlie. We are all heartbroken by her death."
10 days ago.

WAYNE LEWIS, 81, of Chesterville, Maine, died of COVID on Jan. 4, 2023. "Wayne loved home improvement projects, fishing, spending time outdoors, animals, and going out to eat, particularly for breakfast...Above all he loved and was extremely proud of his family."

PHOEBE LISS, 91 of Vestal, New York, died of COVID on Jan. 13, 2021. "Phoebe Fox Liss, beloved mother, quiet feminist, endless optimist...Tragically, she contracted Covid-19 just days before her scheduled vaccine."
My Dad - miss him so much - thank you @FacesOfCOVID
The family makes an earnest plea in Bob's loving memory. @FacesOfCOVID

PENNY KIRSKEY, 65 of Tupelo, Mississippi died of COVID on Jan. 13, 2021. "Penny was a loving mother, and grandmother. She worked hard in her job in the Social Security Administration. She is survived by her husband, John, her 3 adult children, and 11 grandchildren."

ROBERT ROWATT, 67, of Peru, Illinois, died of COVID on Jan. 13, 2022. "Bob was fully vaccinated including a recent booster, but was compromised & at increased risk...Please get vaccinated. Please wear a mask around others...we couldn't save Bob, we might save the next person."

JUAN "CJ" CARO JR., 62, of Lorain, Ohio, died of COVID on Jan. 10, 2021. "Everyone knew him around as 'MR. SOFRITO' because one spoon of his love made everything better. His selfless actions helped anyone in need whether it was food, clothes, or a place to rest your head."
Mom

ANNA LEONARD, 81, of Belmond, Iowa, died of COVID on Jan. 10, 2021. "She enjoyed countless jobs throughout the years. She liked to switch it up and try new things. She was a devoted Catholic and loved to entertain, play cards, and bake. She was so funny. We miss her so much."
FERN HEAD, 67, of Glenwood, Minnesota, died of COVID on Dec. 17, 2022. "Fern loved golf, cooking, bird watching, animals, bingo, and spending time with her family and friends."
MANUELA ANTELO, 52, of Las Vegas, Nevada, died of COVID on Jan. 9, 2021. "My mother was a heart of gold and the most humblest women ever and she fought as hard as she could..."

DR. ROSALIND MITCHELL of New Mexico, died of COVID on Jan. 9, 2021. "Her first love, however, was gardening; playing in the dirt always made her extremely happy...Whether you knew her as Rosalind, Roz, Rozi, or Denise, she was deeply loved by her family and friends..."

EUGENE "GENE" GUYER, 71, of Wilmington, Delaware, died of COVID on Jan. 9, 2021. "Gene started his music career when he was 7 years old, spanning over 64 years. He became a lead guitarist in various bands & his greatest joy was...performing on stage with his daughter Mary."

RYAN KAPES, 16 of Wilmington, Delaware died of COVID on Jan. 9, 2021. "Ryan’s life was full in his short 16 years....You could see the love that Ryan had for his family and friends through his eyes and amazing smile. He will be missed so dearly and deeply forever."
The first @FacesofCOVID story (and surely not the last) of an individual who passed away from COVID in 2023, as we enter our fourth year of this pandemic.

HANNA KIM, 89, of Los Angeles, died of COVID on Jan. 4, 2021. She "was strong, selfless, compassionate, and full of love until her last moments...It broke our hearts to see our optimistic, fun-loving, and talkative matriarch unable to speak her last words while intubated."

BILLY WELCH, 62, of Norco, California, died of COVID on Jan. 4, 2021. "He had a very adventurous life, the Air Force, working on the 1st Space Shuttles in the early 80s...a successful Chiropractor with two offices. He leaves behind his sweetheart, Robin & two beloved children."

NELL HUERTA, of Cozad, Nebraska, died of COVID on Jan. 4, 2021. "She was the type of grandma that never said no to playing or reading books. She hugged with every ounce of her little body. She loved unconditionally and was so loved in return. My family has lost our matriarch."
44,504 people in the U.S. are currently hospitalized with COVID.

JUDITH ANN CHUTE, 77, of La Crosse, Wisconsin, died of Long COVID on Nov. 29, 2020. " She touched so many lives with her kindness and generosity. Beautiful inside and out and truly a special gift from God. Her family will miss her dearly..."

DR. MAYURKUMAR AMIN, 62, of Fresno, California, died of COVID on Jan. 3, 2021. Born in Kenya, "Over his illustrious career he compassionately cared for thousands of vulnerable mental health patients in Fresno and surrounding communities."

JESS BARRETT, 31, of Texas, died of COVID on Jan. 3, 2022. "Jess loved Summers in Colorado with his family, enjoying golf and hiking. He was also a dedicated movie goer and loved all Marvel comic book characters and Star Wars movies."

HOWARD "RANDALL" FAUST JR., 68 of Wichita, Kansas died of COVID on Jan. 3, 2020. "Cousin Randall was a strong protector & doer for his family & friends. Randall will be remembered fondly for demonstrating his love for family & friends, by being there when they needed him most."
We are about to enter our 4th year of the COVID pandemic.

LORI THOMAS, of Des Moines, Iowa, died of complications from Long COVID on Oct. 30, 2022. "Lori volunteered her time at the local Animal Rescue League. She especially enjoyed working with the kittens."

MICHAEL GUGLIELMO, 74, of New York, died of COVID on Jan. 2, 2021. "Family & friends were everything to "Big Mike", also known growing up as "Big Gugs." You could always recognize him by his Allen Edmond shoes. He enjoyed hard work, fixing things & spending time at the beach."

DEBORAH "DEB" FLANIGAN, 73, of Virginia, died of COVID on Dec. 28, 2020. "She loved being a mom and grandmother. She will be missed by her friends and family. She was a funny, fantastic woman with a generous spirit and a heart of gold."

ALEX KOVACH JR., 63, of Greensburg, Pennsylvania, died of COVID on Dec. 28, 2021. "His sense of humor was second-to-none, and he was often cracking jokes...Some would call his jokes corny or dry, but Alex considered them hilarious as a chuckle often followed after each joke."

IRJA DALY, 88, of Gardner, Massachusetts, died of COVID on Dec. 28, 2020. "Through the example of her own life, she taught her family the value of simple but profound pleasures: the love of children...the beauty of nature; and the wisdom of wasting little and wanting less."

CHARLES BARR III, 45, of Bradford, Pennsylvania died of COVID on Dec. 28, 2020. "Charlie was the human manifestation of happiness and self-confidence. His intellectual disability never slowed him down, and he greeted every day as a challenge to make it the best day ever."
People are still dying from Covid-19.
ROBERT "BINSK" EWING, 57, of Hempstead, Texas, died of COVID on Dec. 27, 2021. "Bob was a talented craftsman and handyman, well respected businessman, excellent pool player, and decent golfer."

MANNY PEREZ, 32, of California died of COVID on Dec. 27, 2021. "He loved adventures of all shapes & sizes...making the most of every moment. From sitting at home spending precious moments with the people he loved, to wild travels seeing the word..."

KENNY RAY HILLIS, 60, of Nashville, Tennessee, died of COVID on Dec. 16, 2022. "Kenny loved his family and had a deep relationship with each member of his family. He was the glue that held the family together and he is missed. Fly with the Angels until we are reunited again."

The team at @WBUR 's @cogwbur ( @cloeax & @francesmargaret ) put together this beautiful piece in 2021 remembering him through the words of his daughter: https://wbur.org/cognoscenti/2021/02/19/faces-of-covid-noreen-salman-wasti-frannie-carr-toth-cloe-axelson…

FLORA HENDRICKS, 83, of Mashpee, Massachusetts, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2021. "She loved the Wampanoag community and loved going to the annual Mashpee Pow-Wow's where you could see her helping her son, Bruzzy, sell T-shirts at his stand."

GENNARO "PAPA" AGRILLO of West Brookfield, Massachusetts, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2020. "Always dressed, regardless of the occasion, he loved his local Marshalls. He drove his grandchildren and later great-grandchildren to and from school."

KAROL POWERS-CASE, 84, of Townsend, Delaware, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2020. "Karol enjoyed cooking, music, playing the piano, sewing, reading and politics. She was always the first to tell memorable stories..Her irresistible light shines yet and will be missed by many."

CARLA GUTHRIE, 73, of Troy, Alabama, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2020. "She could be heard singing as she walked her neighborhood listening to her music. She and Gary watched countless sunsets together from their front yard..."
THEODORE TERUYOSHI HINO, of California, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2020. "Ted was known and loved for his humility, generosity and kindness to all, especially to those in need."
ALONZO ELDRIDGE, 62, of Syracuse, New York, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2021. "He had a big personality, a deep love for his family, unmatched resiliency, and a passion for sports. He will be missed."

ANAND MEHENDALE, 67, of Texas, died of COVID on Dec. 19, 2020. "My father was my hero. I became a neurologist because of him. He was my soft place to land & he always listened & valued my brothers, mother & me. He was everyone’s biggest champion & had the biggest heart."

ORON "TOM" SOUDERS, 69, of Brookport, Illinois, died of COVID on Dec. 18, 2021. "My dear brother passed away due to Covid just before Christmas. A husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. He loved driving semi-trucks."

NANCY GRIME, 73, of Wauseon, Ohio, died of COVID on Dec. 18, 2020. "She took pride in her home and loved doing yard work, in particular mowing the lawn. This was her favorite job, as she told Ron many times 'he couldn't mow a straight line.'"

Still working on where @FacesOfCOVID goes next, but it clearly cannot stay here much longer. Send me an email at thefacesofcovid@gmail.com if you haven't yet if you'd like to stay connected to this work.

JOEL ARANA, 50, of Granada Hills, California, died of COVID on Dec. 6, 2020. "Joel was the coolest guy. He was a Halloween nut, fun dad and awesome cousin-in-law. He was a radiologist, TV and film buff and just all around kind human being. He left behind so many broken hearts."

ELIZABETH "BETSY" MCGEHEE, 81 of Covington, Georgia died of COVID on Dec. 6, 2020. "Best mother & grandmother ever. Incredibly smart, funny, outspoken & generous. Known as Mamoo by her one grandchild Benjamin. 3-day Jeopardy winner in '65 while pregnant with first born."

CHESTER "CHET" LEWIS, 77, of Greens Fork, Indiana, died of COVID on Dec. 5, 2021. "You could always count on Chet to send a funny email, or share a story about his frustrations with his adventures in cell phone and 21st century technology."

EARLA "DAWN" DIMITRIADIS, 66, of Stratford, Connecticut died of COVID on Dec. 5, 2020. "Let’s be honest, she was a badass. It is my mother's resiliency that allows me to be here today; if we carry intergenerational trauma, then we also carry intergenerational wisdom & strength."

LEE DALE, 70 of Castle Rock, Colorado died of COVID on Dec. 5, 2020. "...a devoted family man, teacher, and friend, Lee was a true man of faith who did his best to live a life of service to others...a natural peacemaker, a gifted storyteller & a surprisingly good dancer."
FRED GOODSPEED JR., 53, of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, died of COVID on Aug. 3, 2021. "He was a talented bladesmith, a great father, godfather and a friend to all."

CYNTHIA BATES, 58, of West Mifflin, Pennsylvania, died of COVID on Dec. 4, 2021. "Whether taking care of her parents, being out with friends, or playing with her granddaughter...Cindy had the greatest smile, bubbly personality and a terrific attitude!"

LINDA JENKINS, 74, of Indianapolis, Indiana, died of COVID on Dec. 4, 2021. "She was an example of quiet strength that kept the whole family in motion. Amongst her extensive list of precious attributes, Linda will be especially remembered for her compassion and caring spirit."
RACHELLE HOLDAWAY, 48, of Ogden, Utah, died of COVID on Dec. 4, 2021. "Rachelle loved all animals. She opened her heart and home to foster several dogs and cats over the last few years."
Our family celebrated our 2nd Thanksgiving without Jeff. This year included the new grandson he will never meet, Martin Jeffrey. grandpa foreverinourhearts

ISABEL RODRIGUEZ, 78, of Miami, Florida, died of COVID on Nov. 26, 2020. "My mother Isabel was the purest soul you could come across...She was the rock that held our family together and I miss her so much."

LARRY KRAFT, 82, of Rugby, North Dakota, died of COVID on Nov. 26, 2020. "I miss dad every day. Covid took many in our small ND community. His gentle kindness and welcoming smile will not be forgotten...How do we keep his legacy with us in the years ahead."

BETH ANNE GOODWIN, 47, of Newark, West Virginia died of COVID on Nov. 26, 2021. "A short list of the things she loved to do were...sharing any time with her children, cuddling with her granddaughter...& morning coffee time on the porch with her husband."

STEPHEN PATTERSON, 69 of Romeoville, Illinois, died of COVID on Nov. 26, 2020. "I lost my lifelong best friend, mentor, and hijinks buddy. Only 362 days older than me, we bonded early. Never a falling out. I was always proud of my big brother..."

HOWARD WARREN, 76, of Lubbock, Texas, died of COVID on Nov. 26, 2020. "He had a hard life &persevered where others would have quit. This man was a fierce fighter, battling ailments never stopped him from smiling & putting joy in others lives. He passed Thanksgiving Day Morning."

GLENNA MASON, 52, of Grafton, New Hampshire, died of COVID on Nov. 25, 2021. "Glenna was genuine & uncomplicated. She enjoyed hunting, fishing, & ice fishing. She loved holidays, especially Halloween, Thanksgiving, and Christmas..."

DAVID DESROSIERS, 68, of Nashua, New Hampshire, died of COVID on Nov. 25, 2020. "Dave (our dad) was everybody’s friend, he was the life of a party and would light up the room. He would give you the shirt off his back, and would always take time to help someone out."

A quick update: While I'll continue to share stories here (for now!), I'm taking steps to stand up an online database of all of the 8,000+ stories in the coming weeks. If you'd like to be added to the mailing list for updates on that, email me at thefacesofcovid@gmail.com. - Alex

KEITH WISECUP, 25, of Bellefontaine, Ohio, died of COVID on Nov. 10, 2021. "He planned on getting vaccinated but worked so much that he didn't make time. I miss my son so much. He is not just another statistical number. He is my son."
